climbs.name: The Lost Nose
climbs.fa: TR - John "Whitey" MacLean, boulder FA unknown

content.description: Six feet right of Jay's Crack, climb up the blunt arete to the start of the slab then follow the lip out left until you can top out. Highball
content.location: about six feet right of Jay's Crack

content.description: On the left end of the wall, start under an arete and climb up making easy moves to a relatively tricky high top out. If you are not feeling it, you can escape out left.
content.location: left side of the Blacksmith face.

content.description: Climb the great crack on the right side of the Blacksmith face. Fun, but don't fall. The crux is near the top.
content.protection: pads and spot, but don't fall.
content.location: right side of the Blacksmith face. It is the obvious vertical crack.

content.description: Climb the hard (impossible?) face in the center of the tall face right of the Blacksmith. Finally climbed in 2017 by Evan.  Named for obvious stenciled doughboy grafitti...

At the arete right of Jay's Crack, start standing, left hand on arete, right hand on crimp at 5ft . Climb up the arete then move right to the slopey lip. At the lip, head up to the obvious huge pocket/hueco in the slab. High topout. Sit start doesn't add any real difficulty but should be done for the full value movement.
content.protection: Good landing but pads and spotters.

climbs.name: The Blacksmith
climbs.fa: TR -Andrew Sornborger, late  '80s, bouldered by Ward Smith and Mark Sprague, early '00s

content.description: On the left side of the tall overhanging main  face, climb thin moves up the left facing corner formed by the giant flake. Move right across its top,  and up, making a committing move that is hard to reverse and continue up to the scary mantle finish. Ward beat me to the bouldering FA by 3 minutes when I down climbed to brush the top-out off (grr). You will want to make sure the top out is clean when you go for it also.
content.location: The overhanging face with the clinking Champagne glasses on the left side of the wall

content.description: Usually hidden in the trees when the leaves are out, you may be able to catch a glimpse of this area from the loop road by looking NE from the vicinity of the Ball Buster boulder when they are down. This is one of the more extensive chunks of rock at Lincoln Woods, where people used to sometimes set up TRs in the past for the higher problems. With pads they are now getting done more as highballs. At approximately 20-25 feet at spots and occasionally sporting bad landings, a TR might still be a good idea for some lines.   If coming from the The Best Kept Secret area area, you will be dropping down around the left edge of the Main Wall. You will know you are there by the big clinking Champagne glasses graffiti on the otherwise tall, beautiful, gently overhanging Blacksmith face. The far right side of this crag is named after the route Earth Mover. Below are more boulders, including Dream Time. If you keep going east towards Goat Rock, you will pass the Coffin Boulder on the same hillside.
